provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; possibly sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 164 with three other works by Blake (£1.9s. to Francis Turner Palgrave); sold Sotheby's, 19 April 1904, lot 403 (£11.15s. to W. Daniell, probably a dealer); Alice G. E. Carthew by 1914; bequeathed by Carthew to the Tate Gallery, now Tate Collection, in 1940.

desc.objtitle:
Job’s Wife and Other Sketches,
object 1 (Butlin 162 verso)

objnote.p: These pencil sketches are on the verso of Blake's monochrome wash drawing, Job, His Wife and Friends: The Complaint of Job. The sketch of Job's wife, sideways in the middle of this leaf of pencil drawings, is preliminary to Blake's two subsequent versions of the full composition on the recto, The Complaint of Job: "What Is Man that Thou Shouldest Try Him Every Moment?" (Butlin 164) and the large separate engraving of "Job" of 1793. Job's wife is in a different posture in the recto design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Many figures and separate vignettes constitute this drawing. In the center of the leaf is a sitting or squatting and contracted female figure, sketched sideways, with her body facing forward and her head turned to her right. The similarity of this figure to Job's wife in two of Blake's more developed illustrations to The Book of Job, The Complaint of Job: "What Is Man that Thou Shouldest Try Him Every Moment?" (Butlin 164) and the large separate engraving of "Job" of 1793, identifies her. Just above her, rendered in very light pencil lines, may be another figure, sketched sideways and with the head on the right, just above the feet of Job's wife. This might be the frontmost of Job's friends, probably Eliphaz, in the same two more developed renderings of Blake's Job illustrations. In the center of the top half of the leaf, a male(?) figure with long hair sits facing forward and right. He may be a shepherd sitting beneath a large tree. His bent right arm rests in his lap where he holds a lyre between his legs. With his raised, bent left arm, he may be holding a staff or shepherd's crook. On the left side of the lower half of the design, a similar figure, but possibly female, also sits facing right yet looking forward. Her long hair appears to blow in front of her face, and she appears to wear a gown. Her right arm rests in her lap, and she raises her left beside her face. In the lower right corner, a rectangular space contains a pastoral design of a seated figure, likely a shepherd, holding a staff or crook and surrounded by various indeterminate vegetation. There is a second rectangular design positioned just left of center in which a figure appears to stand amongst tree trunks. Various other sketches appear throughout the leaf including a right-facing profile in the lower left corner; a left-facing profile just above the previous visage; a third face just above, rendered as only eyes and eyebrows; another seated figure, sketches sideways near the center left margin; a large face upper left, only the eyes and eyebrows clearly pictured; and a seated figure upper right, sketched sideways.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the leaf is a sitting or squatting and contracted female figure, sketched sideways, with her body facing forward and her head turned to her right. She has long hair; her right arm may be bent across her body. She may wear a gown. The similarity of this figure to Job's wife in two of Blake's more developed illustrations to the Book of Job, The Complaint of Job: "What Is Man that Thou Shouldest Try Him Every Moment?" (Butlin 164) and the large separate engraving of "Job" of 1793, identifies her.

Just above Job's wife (the sitting or squatting figure in the center of the leaf) may be another figure, sketched sideways in very light pencil lines and with the head on the right, just above the feet of Job's wife. The figure leans forward and to the right. This might be the frontmost of Job's friends, probably Eliphaz, in two of Blake's more developed illustrations to the Book of Job, The Complaint of Job: "What Is Man that Thou Shouldest Try Him Every Moment?" (Butlin 164) and the large separate engraving of "Job" of 1793.

Many figures and separate vignettes constitute this drawing. In the center of the top half of the leaf, a male(?) figure with long hair sits facing forward and right. His bent right arm rests in his lap where he holds a lyre between his legs. He may be a shepherd. With his raised, bent left arm, he may be holding a staff or shepherd's crook.
The large seated figure in the upper half of the leaf sits before a large tree trunk. Its roots may be visible right of the seated figure.

Many figures and separate vignettes constitute this drawing. On the left side of the lower half of the design, a female(?) figure sits facing right yet looking forward. Her long hair appears to blow in front of her face, and she likely wears a gown. Her right arm rests in her lap, and she raises her left hand beside her face. Her expression suggests melancholy.

In the lower right corner, a rectangular space contains a pastoral design of a seated figure, likely a male(?) shepherd, holding a staff or crook in his left hand and supporting a lyre with his right, which rests between his legs. The figure, who has long hair and may wear a gown, faces forward.

The shepherd in the lower right corner of the design within framing lines holds a staff or shepherd's crook in his raised left arm and supports a lyre with his right hand. He may sit on a large stone or bank. Lines in the sky may indicate clouds.
In the lower right corner, a framed rectangular space contains a pastoral design of a seated figure surrounded by trees, vines, grass, and/or other indeterminate vegetation.

Many figures and separate vignettes constitute this drawing. There is a framed rectangular design positioned just left of center in which a figure appears to stand amongst tree trunks. This figure faces forward and may hold an object in its right hand, perhaps a shepherd's crook. Forms to the left of the figure's feet may be grazing sheep.
The figure in the framed vignette just left of center stands among tree trunks.
In the second, smaller rectangular design just left of center, a figure stands facing forward, and forms at lower left may indicate grazing sheep.
In the lower left corner, a partially sketched face is visible facing right.
In the lower left corner, above the lowest sketched face, a second visage faces left.
Above the two profiles in the lower left corner of the leaf is a third face, rendered only as eyes and eyebrows facing forward.

A seated figure is sketched sideways left of center. This figure's head is cut off by the edge of the leaf. The figures right arm is bent across the figure's lap; the left arm is bent and raised. This figure is similar to the seated shepherds sketched elsewhere in this design.
Only the eyes and hair of a partial yet large sketch of a face, oriented sideways, are visible in the upper left corner of the design.

A seated figure is sketched sideways upper right, similar to the seated shepherds elsewhere on this leaf. He(?) may hold a lyre between his legs with his lowered right arm, like the large figure to the left. His left leg is bent and his left arm bent upward. His left hand may be touching his face, although his head is cut off by the edge of the leaf.

lg.note: Both lines of the inscription, probably by Frederick Tatham, are written vertically along the right margin of the leaf in the upper right corner.
